Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is to continue the operation and maintenance of the CHILL radar as a NSF National Research Facility. Most of the activities remain the same. CSU/CHILL will continue to participate and expand its activities in the Front Range Observational Network Testbed (FRONT) in collaboration with the NCAR S-Pol, Pawnee (CSU), KFTG (Denver), and KCYS (Cheyenne) radars.

CHILL will operate with S and X bands, making it a unique dual frequency, dual polarized feed radar that is expected to open new avenues of research. CSU will continue to have VCHILL, a educational outreach activity that allows instructors from anywhere to obtain historical CHILL data and to operate the CHILL in real time and display in the classroom setting.

CSU will continue its successful 20 hour research projects, REU projects for engineering and meteorology students and to provide in-house research activities. The facility is available to the research community through competitive research grants and to the broader reserach community through approved cost reimbursable projects.

During year 2 of the Cooperative Agreement, however, NSF will convene a radar workshop and site visit to CHILL. The results of that workshop and the site visit will determine if in the third year NSF will solicit a proposal to continue to operate the radar as a National Facility or to use the third year as the phase out year for the CHILL facility. New technologies, such as phased array radars, mobile radars may make the CHILL radar unnecessary. The unknown factor is the addition of the X-band to the CHILL's S-band. The results during the first two years will help determine how much new science can be obtained.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation provides base support for the CSU-CHILL Radar National Facility. The CSU-CHILL is a state of the art, dual frequency (S and X band) polarimetric Doppler radar. The Facility has supported a variety of research and educational programs during this funding period, in addition to working on a major technical upgrade, centered around the addition of a solid state S band transmitter donated by our industrial partner, Raytheon.

Some research highlights include:

The Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry Project (DC3; summer 2012) studied ways in which thunderstorms produce and redistribute chemical species (for example, the production of nitrogen oxides by lightning and subsequent ozone production). Ground-based radar observations were done at three different locations, one being the CSU-CHILL radar in Colorado. Multi-Doppler analyses allowed the three dimensional air motions within the storms to be determined and CHILL polarimetric data provided detailed maps of hydrometeor types. High resolution mappings of lightning discharges, a major source of some nitrogen oxides, were done using a special network of VHF receiving stations. Three research aircraft sampled the concentrations of atmospheric chemical constituents near and within the thunderstorms. The analyses of the data collected in the DC3 project are providing new insights into cloud electrification processes and chemical reactions that occur within thunderstorms, as well as exchange with the lower stratosphere.

The Front Range Orographic Storms Project (FROST, winter 2012 – 2013) investigated the structure and evolution of winter storms along the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains in Colorado. These observations benefitted from the very high spatial resolution (0.3 degree antenna pattern beam width), dual polarization observations offered by the 3 cm wavelength channel of the CSU-CHILL radar. These detailed observations provided new insights into the localized regions where rapid ice particle growth occurs in elevated regions of winter clouds. The identification of these regions should help operational forecasters refine their short term forecasts of areas of significant surface snowfall rates.

Support of the CHILL Microphysical Investigation of Electrification (CHILL-MIE) project (summer 2013) provided simultaneous measurements of electrified storms at both X and S band wavelengths. The analysis of differences between various aspects of the X and S band signal returns from regions within thunderstorms is used to identify areas where a water coating exists on the outer surface of ~1 cm diameter ice particles (wet hail). It is believed that the existence of this water surface is an important factor controlling the electrical charge separation that occurs when smaller ice particles impact the wet hail, producing so-called inverted charge structures where positive electrical charge is situated beneath upper negative charge. These storms often produce severe weather and generate very powerful cloud-to-ground flashes.

Support of the Multi-Angle Snowflake Camera and Radar Project (MASCRAD; winter 2014-2015). This project was centered on the collection of digital photographs of falling snow particles from an array of five cameras that view a common sampling volume. The individual camera images are combined to give 3D representations of the ice / air structures of the snowflakes. Theoretical calculations of the returns that these particles should present to a radar are compared against CSU-CHILL observations. This improved knowledge of the physical and radar characteristics of snow particles should benefit the public at large through increased accuracy in the radar-estimation of snow accumulations.
